verses.english: When Jesus saw her, He called her and said to her, "Woman, you are freed from your infirmity."

verses.latin: Et imposuit illi manus: et statim directa est, et glorificabat Deum.
verses.english: And He laid His hands on her; and immediately she was made straight, and glorified God.

verses.latin: Respondens autem archisynagogus, indignans quia sabbato curasset Jesus, dicebat turbae: Sex dies sunt in quibus oportet operari: in his ergo venite, et curate, et non in die sabbati.
verses.english: And the ruler of the synagogue, indignant that Jesus had cured on the Sabbath, said to the crowd, "There are six days on which work ought to be done; come, therefore, and be cured on those days, and not on the Sabbath day."

verses.latin: Respondens autem Dominus, dixit ei: Hypocrita, unusquisque vestrum sabbato non solvit bovem suum, aut asinum a praesepio, et ducit ad potandum?
verses.english: The Lord answered him, "Hypocrite, does not each one of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his ass from the manger and lead them away to water?

verses.latin: Hanc autem filiam Abraham, quam alligavit Satanas ecce annis decem et octo, non oportuit solvi a vinculo hoc die sabbati?
verses.english: And ought not this daughter of Abraham, whom Satan has bound for eighteen years, be loosed from this bond on the Sabbath day?"

verses.latin: Et cum haec diceret, erubescebant omnes adversarii ejus: et omnis populus gaudebat in universis quae gloriose fiebant ab eo.
verses.english: And when He said these things, all His adversaries were put to shame; and all the people were rejoicing at all the glorious things that were being done by Him.

verses.latin: Dicebat ergo: Cui simile est regnum Dei? et cui similem illud comparabo?
verses.english: He was saying therefore: "To what is the kingdom of God like? And to what shall I compare it?

verses.latin: Simile est grano sinapis, quod acceptum homo misit in hortum suum, et crevit, et factum est in arborem magnam, et volucres caeli requieverunt in ramis ejus.
verses.english: It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his garden; and it grew and became a great tree, and the birds of the air lodged in its branches."

verses.latin: Et iterum dixit: Cui similem faciam regnum Dei?
verses.english: And again He said, "To what shall I liken the kingdom of God?

verses.latin: Simile est fermento, quod acceptum mulier misit in farinae sartaginem, donec totum fermentaretur.
verses.english: It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, until it was all leavened."

verses.latin: Et ibat per civitates et castella, docens, et iter faciens in Jerusalem.
verses.english: And He was going through the cities and villages, teaching and journeying towards Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Ait autem illi quidam: Domine, si pauci sunt qui salvantur?
verses.english: And someone said to Him, "Lord, are only a few being saved?"

verses.latin: Ipse autem dixit ad illos: Certate intrare per angustam portam: quia multi, dico vobis, quaerent intrare, et non poterunt.
verses.english: But He said to them, "Strive to enter through the narrow gate, for many, I say to you, will seek to enter and will not be able.

verses.latin: Cum autem coeperit paterfamilias surrexisse, et claudere ostium, et incipitis foris stare, et pulsare ostium, dicentes: Domine, aperi nobis: et respondens dicet vobis: Nescio vos unde sitis.
verses.english: When once the householder has risen and shut the door, you will begin to stand outside and knock at the door, saying, 'Lord, open to us.' And He will answer and say to you, 'I do not know where you are from.'

verses.latin: Tunc incipietis dicere: Manducavimus coram te, et bibimus, et in plateis nostris docuisti.
verses.english: Then you will begin to say, 'We ate and drank in Your presence, and You taught in our streets.'

verses.latin: Et dicet vobis: Nescio vos unde sitis: recedite a me, omnes operarii iniquitatis.
verses.english: And He will say to you, 'I do not know where you are from. Depart from Me, all you workers of iniquity.'

verses.latin: Ibi erit fletus et stridor dentium, cum videritis Abraham, et Isaac, et Jacob, et omnes prophetas in regno Dei, vos autem expellimini foras.
verses.english: There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and yourselves thrust out.

verses.latin: Et venient ab oriente et occidente, et ab aquilone et austro, et recumbent in regno Dei.
verses.english: And they will come from the east and the west, and from the north and the south, and will recline at table in the kingdom of God.

verses.latin: Et ecce sunt novissimi qui erunt primi, et sunt primi qui erunt novissimi.
verses.english: And behold, there are last who will be first, and there are first who will be last.

verses.latin: In ipsa hora accesserunt quidam pharisaei, dicentes illi: Exi, et vade hinc: quia Herodes vult te occidere.
verses.english: At that very hour, some Pharisees came up and said to Him, "Go away and depart from here, for Herod wishes to kill You."

verses.latin: Et ait illis: Ite, et dicite vulpi illi: Ecce ejicio daemonia, et curas perficio hodie et cras, et tertia die consummor.
verses.english: And He said to them, "Go and tell that fox, 'Behold, I cast out demons and perform cures today and tomorrow, and the third day I am perfected.'

verses.latin: Verumtamen oportet me hodie et cras et sequenti die ambulare: non enim capit prophetam perire extra Jerusalem.
verses.english: Nevertheless, I must go on My way today and tomorrow and the next day; for it is not possible for a prophet to perish outside Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Jerusalem, Jerusalem, quae occidis prophetas, et lapidas eos qui missi sunt ad te: quoties volui congregare filios tuos, quemadmodum gallina nidum suum sub alas, et noluisti?
verses.english: Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to her, how often would I have gathered your children together as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you would not!

verses.latin: Ecce relinquitur vobis domus vestra deserta. Dico autem vobis, quod non videatis me donec veniatis, cum dixeritis: Benedictus, qui venit in nomine Domini.
verses.english: Behold, your house is left to you desolate. And I say to you that you shall not see Me until you say, 'Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum introisset Iesus in domum cujusdam principis pharisæorum sabbato manducare panem, et ipsi observabant eum.
verses.english: One sabbath, Jesus went to eat bread in the house of a leader of the Pharisees, and they were all watching Him closely.

verses.latin: Et ecce homo quidam hydropicus erat ante illos.
verses.english: A man suffering from dropsy was present before them.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Iesus, dixit ad legisperitos et pharisæos, dicens: Si licet sabbato curare?
verses.english: Jesus responded, asking the lawyers and Pharisees, “Is it permissible to heal on the Sabbath?”

verses.latin: At illi tacuerunt. Et apprehendens sanavit eum, et dimisit.
verses.english: They remained silent. Then, taking hold of the man, He healed him and let him go.

verses.latin: Et respondens, dixit ad illos: Cujus vestrum asinus aut bos in puteum cadet, quem non continuo extrahet die sabbati?
verses.english: Then, He said to them, “If your donkey or ox falls into a well, who among you won’t immediately pull it out, even on the Sabbath?”

verses.latin: Et non poterant ad hæc respondere illi.
verses.english: They were not able to respond to these things.

verses.latin: Dicebat autem et ad eos qui invitati erant parabolam, intendens quomodo primos discubitus eligerent, dicens illis:
verses.english: He also told a parable to those who were invited, as He observed how they chose the best places at the table, saying to them:

verses.latin: Cum invitatus fueris ad nuptias, non recumbas in primo loco, ne forte honoratior te sit invitatus ab eo;
verses.english: “When you are invited to a wedding feast, don’t recline in the best place, lest a more important person than you has been invited.

verses.latin: et veniens qui te et illum invitavit, dicat tibi: Da huic locum. Et tunc incipias cum rubore novissimum locum tenere.
verses.english: Then, the one who invited you and the other guest may come and say to you, ‘Give this man your place.’ Then you would begin to take the lowest place with shame.

verses.latin: Sed cum vocatus fueris, vade, recumbe in novissimo loco: ut cum venerit qui te invitavit, dicat tibi: Amice, ascende superius. Tunc erit tibi gloria coram simul discumbentibus.
verses.english: But when you are invited, go and recline in the lowest place, so that when the one who invited you comes, he may say to you, ‘Friend, move up higher.’ Then it will be a glory to you in the sight of all those at table with you.

verses.latin: Quia omnis qui se exaltat, humiliabitur; et qui se humiliat, exaltabitur.
verses.english: For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and the one who humbles himself will be exalted.”

verses.latin: Dicebat autem et ei qui invitaverat eum: Quando facis prandium aut cœnam, noli vocare amicos tuos, neque fratres tuos, neque cognatos, neque vicinos divites: ne forte et ipsi te reinvitent, et fiat tibi retributio.
verses.english: He also said to the one who invited Him: “When you give a lunch or a dinner, don’t invite your friends, brothers, relatives, or rich neighbors. Otherwise, they may invite you back, and you will be repaid.

verses.latin: Sed cum facis convivium, voca pauperes, debiles, claudos, cæcos;
verses.english: But when you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.

verses.latin: et beatus eris, quia non habent unde retribuant tibi: retribuetur enim tibi in resurrectione justorum.
verses.english: Then you will be blessed, because they have no means to repay you. For you will be repaid at the resurrection of the just.”

verses.latin: Hæc audiens quidam ex simul discumbentibus, dixit illi: Beatus qui manducabit panem in regno Dei.
verses.english: Hearing this, one of those reclining at table with Him said to Him, “Blessed is the one who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!”

verses.latin: At ipse dixit ei: Homo quidam fecit cœnam magnam, et vocavit multos.
verses.english: But He said to him: “A man once gave a great dinner and invited many.

verses.latin: Et misit servum suum hora cœnæ dicere invitatis ut venirent, quia jam parata sunt omnia.
verses.english: And at the time of the dinner, he sent his servant to tell those who were invited to come, because everything was now ready.

verses.latin: Et cœperunt simul omnes excusare. Primus dixit ei: Villam emi, et necesse habeo exire et videre illam: rogo te, habe me excusatum.
verses.english: But they all began to make excuses together. The first one said to him, ‘I bought a piece of land, and I must go out and see it. I ask you, consider me excused.’

verses.latin: Et alter dixit: Jumenta emi quinque, et eo probare illa: rogo te, habe me excusatum.
verses.english: And another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I’m going to try them out. I ask you, consider me excused.’

verses.latin: Et alius dixit: Uxorem duxi, et ideo non possum venire.
verses.english: And another said, ‘I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.’

verses.latin: Et reversus servus, nuntiavit hæc domino suo. Tunc iratus paterfamilias, dixit servo suo: Exi cito in plateas et vicos civitatis, et pauperes, et debiles, et claudos, et cæcos introduce huc.
verses.english: The servant returned and reported these things to his master. Then, the master of the house, angered, said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.’

verses.latin: Et ait servus: Domine, factum est ut imperasti, et adhuc locus est.
verses.english: The servant said, ‘Master, what you ordered has been done, and there is still room.’

verses.latin: Et dixit dominus servo: Exi in vias et saepes, et compelle intrare, ut impleatur domus mea.
verses.english: And the master said to the servant, ‘Go out to the highways and hedges, and compel people to come in, that my house may be filled.’

verses.latin: Dico enim vobis, quod nemo ex illis viris qui vocati sunt, gustabit cœnam meam.
verses.english: I tell you, that none of those men who were invited will taste my dinner.”

verses.latin: Magnæ autem turbæ ibant cum eo: et conversus, dixit ad illos:
verses.english: Large crowds were traveling with Him; and turning, He said to them:

verses.latin: Si quis venit ad me, et non odit patrem suum, et matrem, et uxorem, et filios, et fratres, et sorores, adhuc autem et animam suam, non potest meus esse discipulus.
verses.english: “If anyone comes to Me and does not hate his father, mother, wife, children, brothers, and sisters, and even his own life, he cannot be My disciple.

verses.latin: Et qui non bajulat crucem suam, et sequitur me, non potest meus esse discipulus.
verses.english: And whoever does not carry his own cross and follow Me cannot be My disciple.

verses.latin: Quis enim ex vobis volens turrim ædificare, non prius sedens computat impensas, si habeat ad perficiendum?
verses.english: For which of you, wishing to build a tower, does not first sit down and calculate the cost to see if he has enough to complete it?

verses.latin: ne forte, positis fundamentis, et non valens perficere, omnes qui vident, incipiant illudere ei,
verses.english: Otherwise, after laying the foundation but not being able to complete it, all who see it may begin to ridicule him,

verses.latin: dicentes: Quia hic homo cœpit ædificare, et non potuit consummare.
verses.english: saying, ‘This man began to build but was not able to finish.’

verses.latin: Aut quí rex iturus pugnare adversus alium regem, non sedens prius cogitat si possit cum decem millibus occurrere ei qui cum viginti millibus venit contra se?
verses.english: Or what king, going to war against another king, does not first sit down and consider whether he is able with ten thousand men to meet the one who comes against him with twenty thousand?

verses.latin: Alioquin, dum ille adhuc longe est, legationem mittens, rogat ea quæ pacis sunt.
verses.english: If he is not able, while the other is still far away, he sends a delegation and asks for terms of peace.

verses.latin: Sic ergo omnis ex vobis qui non renuntiat omnibus quæ possidet, non potest meus esse discipulus.
verses.english: So, in the same way, whoever of you does not renounce all that he possesses cannot be My disciple.

verses.latin: Bonum est sal: quod si sal evanuerit, in quo condietur?
verses.english: Salt is good; but if the salt loses its flavor, with what will it be seasoned?

verses.latin: Neque in terram, neque in sterquilinium utile est: foras mittunt illud. Qui habet aures audiendi, audiat.
verses.english: It is neither good for the land nor for the manure pile; they throw it out. Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.”

verses.latin: Appropinquabant autem illi publicani et peccatores, ut audirent illum.
verses.english: The tax collectors and other sinners were approaching Jesus to listen to Him.

verses.latin: Et murmurabant pharisæi et scribæ, dicentes: Quia hic peccatores recipit, et manducat cum illis.
verses.english: But the Pharisees and scribes were murmuring. They said, “This man welcomes sinners and eats with them.”

verses.latin: Dixit autem ad illos hanc parabolam, dicens:
verses.english: He then told them this parable:

verses.latin: Quis homo ex vobis habens centum oves, et si perdiderit unam ex illis, nonne relinquit nonaginta novem in deserto, et vadit ad illam quæ perierat, donec inveniat eam?
verses.english: “If one of you has one hundred sheep, and loses one of them, won't you leave the ninety-nine in the wilderness and go after the one that is lost until you find it?

verses.latin: Et cum invenerit eam, imponit in humeros suos gaudens:
verses.english: And when he has found it, he puts it on his shoulders rejoicing.

verses.latin: et veniens domum, convocat amicos et vicinos, dicens illis: Congratulamini mihi, quia inveni ovem meam, quæ perierat.
verses.english: When he arrives home, he calls his friends and neighbors, saying to them: ‘Rejoice with me because I have found my sheep that was lost.’”

verses.latin: Dico vobis, quod ita gaudium erit in cælo super uno peccatore pœnitentiam agente, quam super nonaginta novem justis, qui non indigent pœnitentia.
verses.english: “I tell you, there will be more joy in the sky over one sinner who repents than over ninety-nine righteous people who do not need repentance.”

verses.latin: Aut quæ mulier habens drachmas decem, si perdiderit drachmam unam, nonne accendit lucernam, et everrit domum, et quærit diligenter, donec inveniat?
verses.english: “Or what woman, if she has ten silver coins, if she loses one, does she not light a lamp, sweep the house, and diligently search until she finds it?

verses.latin: Et cum invenerit, convocat amicas et vicinas, dicens: Congratulamini mihi, quia inveni drachmam, quam perdideram.
verses.english: When she finds it, she calls her friends and neighbors, saying: ‘Rejoice with me because I have found the coin that I had lost.’”

verses.latin: Ita dico vobis, gaudium est coram angelis Dei super uno peccatore pœnitentiam agente.
verses.english: “So I tell you, there is joy before the angels of God over one sinner who repents.”

verses.latin: Dixit autem: Homo quidam habuit duos filios:
verses.english: And He said: “A certain man had two sons:

verses.latin: et dixit adolescentior ex illis patri: Pater, da mihi portionem substantiæ quæ me contingit. Et divisit illis substantiam.
verses.english: The younger one said to his father, ‘Father, give me the portion of inheritance that belongs to me.’ So the father divided his property between them.

verses.latin: Et non post multos dies, congregatis omnibus, adolescentior filius peregre profectus est in regionem longinquam: et ibi dissipavit substantiam suam vivendo lixuriose.
verses.english: Not long after, the younger son gathered all his possessions and set off for a distant country. There, he squandered his wealth in wild living.

verses.latin: Postquam autem consummasset omnia, facta est fames valida in regione illa, et ipse cœpit egere.
verses.english: When he had spent everything, a severe famine arose in that country, and he began to be in need.

verses.latin: Et abiit, et adhæsit uni de civibus regionis illius: et misit illum in villam suam, ut pasceret porcos.
verses.english: So he went and hired himself out to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him to his fields to feed swine.

verses.latin: Et desiderabat implere ventrem suum de siliquis quas porci manducabant: et nemo illi dabat.
verses.english: And he longed to fill his stomach with the pods that the swine were eating, but no one gave him any.

verses.latin: In se autem reversus, dixit: Quot mercennarii patris mei abundant panibus, dum ego fame pereo?
verses.english: Then, when he came to himself, he said, ‘How many of my father's hired servants have more than enough bread, and I am dying here of hunger?

verses.latin: Surgam, et ibo ad patrem meum, et dicam ei: Pater, peccavi in cælum et coram te:
verses.english: I will arise and go to my father and I will say to him, “Father, I have sinned against the sky and before you.

verses.latin: et jam non sum dignus vocari filius tuus: fac me sicut unum de mercennariis tuis.
verses.english: I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Make me as one of your hired servants.”

verses.latin: Et surgens venit ad patrem suum. Cum autem adhuc longe esset, vidit illum pater ipsius, et misericordia motus est, et currens, cecidit super collum ejus, et osculatus est eum.
verses.english: So he arose and went to his father. But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and felt compassion, and ran and embraced him, and kissed him.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei filius: Pater, peccavi in cælum et coram te: et jam non sum dignus vocari filius tuus.
verses.english: And the son said to him, ‘Father, I have sinned against the sky and before you; I am no longer worthy to be called your son.’

verses.latin: Dixit autem pater ad servos suos: Cito proferte stolam primam, et induite illum, et date annulum in manum ejus, et calceamenta in pedes ejus:
verses.english: But the father said to his servants, ‘Quickly bring out the best robe and put it on him, and put a ring on his hand and sandals on his feet.

verses.latin: et adducite vitulum saginatum, et occidite: et manducemus, et epulemur:
verses.english: Also bring the fattened calf and kill it. Let us eat and celebrate.

verses.latin: quia hic filius meus mortuus erat, et revixit: perierat, et inventus est. Et cœperunt epulari.
verses.english: For this my son was dead and has come back to life; he was lost, and is found.’ And they began to celebrate.

verses.latin: Filius autem ejus senior erat in agro: et cum veniret, et appropinquaret domui, audivit symphoniam et chorum:
verses.english: Now his older son was in the field, and as he came and drew near to the house, he heard music and dancing.

verses.latin: et vocavit unum de servis, et interrogabat quidnam hæc essent.
verses.english: He summoned one of the servants and asked what these things meant.

verses.latin: Qui dixit ei: Frater tuus venit, et occidit pater tuus vitulum saginatum, quia salvum illum suscepit.
verses.english: The servant told him, ‘Your brother has come, and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he has received him back safe and sound.’

verses.latin: Iratus est autem, et nolebat introire. Pater itaque ejus egressus, cœpit rogare eum.
verses.english: But he was angry and refused to go in. Therefore his father came out and began to plead with him.

verses.latin: Qui respondens, dixit patri suo: Ecce tot annis servo tibi, et numquam mandatum tuum præterivi: et numquam dedisti mihi hædum, ut cum amicis meis epularer:
verses.english: But he answered and said to his father, ‘Look, these many years I have served you, and I never disobeyed your command. Yet you never gave me a young goat, so that I might celebrate with my friends.

verses.latin: sed postquam hic filius tuus, qui devoravit substantiam suam cum meretricibus, venit, occidisti ei vitulum saginatum.
verses.english: But when this son of yours, who has devoured your property with prostitutes, came, you killed the fattened calf for him.’

verses.latin: At ipse dixit illi: Fili, tu semper mecum es, et omnia mea tua sunt.
verses.english: And he said to him, ‘Son, you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.

verses.latin: Sed oportebat gaudere et lætari, quia frater tuus hic mortuus erat, et revixit: perierat, et inventus est.
verses.english: But it was fitting to celebrate and rejoice, for your brother was dead and has come back to life, and was lost and is found.’”

verses.latin: Dicebat autem et ad discipulos: Homo quidam erat dives, qui habebat villicum: et hic diffamatus est apud illum quasi dissipasset bona ipsius.
verses.english: Jesus also said to his disciples: “There was a certain rich man who had a manager. This manager was accused of wasting his possessions.

verses.latin: Et vocavit illum, et ait illi: Quid hoc audio de te? redde rationem villicationis tuae: jam enim non poteris villicare.
verses.english: So the rich man called him and said, ‘What is this that I hear about you? Give an account of your management, because you can no longer be my manager.’

verses.latin: Respondens autem villicus, dixit intra se: Quid faciam? quia dominus meus aufert a me villicationem. fodere non valeo, mendicare erubesco.
verses.english: The manager said to himself, ‘What am I going to do now that my master is taking away my management? I cannot dig, and I am ashamed to beg.’

verses.latin: Scio quid faciam, ut cum amotus fuero a villicatione, recipiant me in domos suas.
verses.english: ‘I know what I will do, so that, when I am removed from my management, people may welcome me into their houses.’

verses.latin: Convocatis itaque singulis de dominis suis, qui debebant villico, dixit primo: Quantum debes domino meo?
verses.english: So he summoned each one of his master's debtors. He asked the first, ‘How much do you owe my master?’

verses.latin: At ille dixit: Centum batos olei. Ait illi: Sume scriptum, et sede cito, et scribe quinquaginta.
verses.english: He replied, ‘One hundred measures of olive oil.’ The manager said to him, ‘Here is your bill. Sit down quickly and write fifty.’

verses.latin: Deinde alii dixit: Tu autem quantum debes? Qui ait: Centum choros tritici. Ait illi: Sume scriptum, et scribe octoginta.
verses.english: Then he asked another, ‘And how much do you owe?’ He replied, ‘One hundred measures of wheat.’ He said to him, ‘Take your bill and write eighty.’

verses.latin: Et laudavit dominus villicum iniquitatis, quod prudenter fecisset: quia filii hujus saeculi prudentiores filiis lucis in generatione sua sunt.
verses.english: And the master commended the dishonest manager because he had acted shrewdly. For the sons of this world are more shrewd in their generation than the sons of light.

verses.latin: Et ego vobis dico: Facite vobis amicos de mammona iniquitatis: ut, cum defeceritis, recipiant vos in aeterna tabernacula.
verses.english: And I tell you, make friends for yourselves by means of the wealth of unrighteousness so that when it fails, they may receive you into the eternal dwellings.

verses.latin: Qui fidelis est in minimo, et in magno fidelis est: et qui in minimo iniquus est, et in magno iniquus est.
verses.english: He who is faithful in a very little thing is faithful also in much. And he who is unjust in a very little thing is unjust also in much.

verses.latin: Si ergo in iniquo mammona fideles non fuistis: quod verum est, quis credet vobis?
verses.english: If therefore you have not been faithful in the unrighteous wealth, who will trust you with the true wealth?

verses.latin: Et si in alieno fideles non fuistis: quod vestrum est, quis dabit vobis?
verses.english: And if you have not been faithful with what belongs to another, who will give you what is your own?

verses.latin: Non potest servus duobus dominis servire: aut enim unum odiet, et alterum diliget: aut unum sustinebit, et alterum contemnet. Non potestis Deo servire et mammonae.
verses.english: No servant can serve two masters. For either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon.

verses.latin: Audiebant autem omnia haec pharisaei, qui erant avari: et deridebant eum.
verses.english: Now the Pharisees, who were lovers of money, were listening to all these things, and they ridiculed Him.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad illos: Vos estis qui justificatis vosmetipsos coram hominibus, sed Deus novit corda vestra: quia quod hominibus altum est, abominatio est ante Deum.
verses.english: And He said to them, “You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts. For what is exalted among men is an abomination in the sight of God.

verses.latin: Lex et prophetae usque ad Joannem: ex eo regnum Dei evangelizatur, et omnis in illud vim facit.
verses.english: The Law and the Prophets were until John. Since then the kingdom of God is preached, and everyone forces his way into it.

verses.latin: Facilius est autem caelum et terram transire, quam de lege unum apicem cadere.
verses.english: But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of a letter of the Law to fail.

verses.latin: Omnis qui dimittit uxorem suam, et ducit alteram, moechatur: et qui dimissam a viro ducit, moechatur.
verses.english: Everyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and he who marries a woman divorced from her husband commits adultery.

verses.latin: Homo quidam erat dives, et induebatur purpura et bysso: et epulabatur quotidie splendide.
verses.english: “There was a certain rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen, and who feasted sumptuously every day.

verses.latin: Et erat quidam mendicus, nomine Lazarus, qui jacebat ante ostium ejus, ulceribus plenus,
verses.english: And at his gate was laid a certain beggar named Lazarus, covered with sores,

verses.latin: cupiens saturari de micis quae cadebant de mensa divitis: sed et canes veniebant, et lingebant ulcera ejus.
verses.english: longing to be fed with the crumbs that fell from the rich man’s table. Moreover, the dogs came and licked his sores.

verses.latin: Factum est autem ut moreretur mendicus, et portaretur ab angelis in sinum Abrahae. Mortuus est autem et dives: et sepultus est in inferno.
verses.english: So it was that the beggar died and was carried away by the angels to Abraham’s bosom. The rich man also died and was buried in hell.

verses.latin: Et elevans oculos suos cum esset in tormentis, vidit Abraham a longe, et Lazarum in sinu ejus:
verses.english: And in hell, being in torment, he lifted up his eyes and saw Abraham far away and Lazarus in his bosom.

verses.latin: et ipse clamans dixit: Pater Abraham, miserere mei, et mitte Lazarum ut intinguat extremum digiti sui in aquam, et refrigeret linguam meam: quia crucior in hac flamma.
verses.english: And he cried out and said, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am tormented in this flame.’

verses.latin: Et dixit illi Abraham: Fili, memor esto quia recepisti bona in vita tua, et Lazarus similiter mala: nunc autem hic consolatur, tu vero cruciaris:
verses.english: But Abraham said, ‘Son, remember that in your lifetime you received good things, and Lazarus in like manner evil things. But now he is comforted here, and you are tormented.’

verses.latin: et praeterea in omnibus his, inter nos et vos, magnum chaos firmatum est: ut hi qui volunt hinc transire ad vos, non possint, neque inde huc transire.
verses.english: And besides all this, between us and you a great chasm has been fixed, so that those who want to pass from here to you cannot, nor can those from there pass to us.’

verses.latin: Et dixit: Rogo ergo te pater, ut mittas eum in domum patris mei:
verses.english: And he said, ‘Then I beg you, father, that you send him to my father’s house—

verses.latin: habeo enim quinque fratres: ut testetur illis, ne et ipsi veniant in hunc locum tormenti.
verses.english: for I have five brothers—so that he may warn them, lest they also come to this place of torment.’

verses.latin: Et ait illi Abraham: Habent Moysen et prophetas: audiant illos.
verses.english: But Abraham said, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets; let them hear them.’

verses.latin: Qui dixit: Non, pater Abraham: sed si quis ex mortuis ierit ad eos, poenitentiam agent.
verses.english: And he said, ‘No, father Abraham, but if someone goes to them from the dead, they will repent.’

verses.latin: Ait illi autem: Si Moysen et prophetas non audiunt, neque si quis ex mortuis resurrexerit, credent.
verses.english: He said to him, ‘If they do not hear Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be persuaded though someone rises from the dead.’

verses.latin: Dixit autem ad discipulos suos: Impossibile est ut non veniant scandala: vae autem illi per quem veniunt.
verses.english: Then Jesus said to his disciples: "It is impossible that no scandals come, but woe to him by whom they come!"

verses.latin: Expedit ei si lapis molaris imponatur circa collum ejus, et projiciatur in mare, quam ut scandalizet unum de pusillis istis.
verses.english: It is better for him if a millstone is put around his neck and he is thrown into the sea, than that he should scandalize one of these little ones.

verses.latin: Attendite vobis. Quod si peccaverit in te frater tuus, corripe eum: et si poenitentiam egerit, dimitte illi.
verses.english: Be careful about this. If your brother sins against you, rebuke him; and if he repents, forgive him.

verses.latin: Et si septies in die peccaverit in te, et septies conversus fuerit ad te, dicens: Pœnitet me, dimitte illi.
verses.english: And if he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times a day turns back to you saying, 'I repent,' you must forgive him.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt apostoli Domino: Adauge nobis fidem.
verses.english: And the apostles said to the Lord, "Increase our faith."

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus: Si habueritis fidem sicut granum sinapis, dicetis huic monti: Transfer te inde huc, et transferret se: et nihil vobis impossibile erit.
verses.english: And the Lord said: "If you have faith as a grain of mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move; and nothing will be impossible for you."

verses.latin: Quis autem vestrum habens servum arantem aut pascentem, qui regresso de agro, dicet illi: Statim transi, et recumbe?
verses.english: But who of you, having a servant plowing or feeding sheep, will say to him when he comes in from the field, 'Come at once and recline at table'?

verses.latin: Et nonne dicet illi: Para quod cœnem, et præcinge te, et ministra mihi, donec edam et bibam, et post hæc tu manducabis, et bibes?
verses.english: And will he not say to him, 'Prepare my dinner, and gird yourself and serve me, until I have eaten and drunk; and afterward you shall eat and drink'?

verses.latin: Numquid gratiam illi agit, quia fecit quæ ei imperata sunt? Non puto.
verses.english: Does he thank that servant because he did the things commanded him? I do not think so.

verses.latin: Ita et vos cum feceritis omnia quæ præcepta sunt vobis, dicite: Servi inutiles sumus: quod debuimus facere, fecimus.
verses.english: So you also, when you have done all that is commanded you, say, 'We are unworthy servants; we have done what we ought to do.'

verses.latin: Et factum est, dum iret in Ierusalem, et ipse transiebat per mediam Samariam et Galilæam.
verses.english: And it came to pass as He was going to Jerusalem, that He passed through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.

verses.latin: Et cum ingrederetur quoddam castellum, occurrerunt ei decem viri leprosi: qui steterunt procul:
verses.english: And as He entered a certain village, there met Him ten men who were lepers, who stood afar off.

verses.latin: et levaverunt vocem, dicentes: Iesu præceptor, miserere nostri.
verses.english: And they lifted up their voices, saying, "Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!"

verses.latin: Quos ut vidit, dixit: Ite, ostendite vos sacerdotibus. Et factum est, dum irent, mundati sunt.
verses.english: And when He saw them, He said to them, "Go, show yourselves to the priests." And it happened that as they went, they were cleansed.

verses.latin: Unus autem ex illis, ut vidit quod mundatus est, regressus est, cum magna voce magnificans Deum:
verses.english: And one of them, when he saw that he was healed, returned, glorifying God with a loud voice,

verses.latin: et cecidit in faciem ante pedes ejus, gratias agens: et hic erat Samaritanus.
verses.english: and he fell on his face at His feet, giving thanks to Him. And he was a Samaritan.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Jesus, dixit: Nonne decem mundati sunt? et ubi sunt novem?
verses.english: And Jesus answering, said: "Were there not ten cleansed? Where are the nine?

verses.latin: Non est inventus qui rediret, et daret gloriam Deo, nisi hic alienigena.
verses.english: Was there not any found to return and give glory to God, except this foreigner?

verses.latin: Et dicebat illi: Surge, vade: fides tua te salvum fecit.
verses.english: And He said to him, "Arise, go your way; your faith has made you whole."

verses.latin: Interrogatus autem a pharisæis, quando regnum Dei venit, respondit eis, et dixit: Non venit regnum Dei cum observatione:
verses.english: And when He was asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, He answered them and said, "The kingdom of God does not come with observation;"

verses.latin: neque dicent: Ecce hic, aut ecce illic. Ecce enim regnum Dei intra vos est.
verses.english: nor will they say, 'See here!' or 'See there!' For indeed, the kingdom of God is within you."

verses.latin: Et dixit ad discipulos: Venient dies quando desideretis unum diem Filii hominis videre, et non videbitis.
verses.english: Then He said to the disciples, "The days will come when you will desire to see one of the days of the Son of Man, and you will not see it.

verses.latin: Et dicent vobis: Ecce hic, et ecce illic: nolite ire, neque sequamini.
verses.english: And they will say to you, 'Look here!' or 'Look there!' Do not go, nor follow them.

verses.latin: Nam sicut fulgur, cum coruscat, de sub cœlo in ea quæ sub cœlo sunt lucet: ita erit Filius hominis in die suo.
verses.english: For as the lightning flashes out of one part under heaven, and shines to the other part under heaven, so also will the Son of Man be in His day.

verses.latin: Sed primum oportet illum multa pati, et reprobari a generatione hac.
verses.english: But first He must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation.

verses.latin: Et sicut factum est in diebus Noe, ita erit et in diebus Filii hominis:
verses.english: And as it was in the days of Noah, so shall it also be in the days of the Son of Man:

verses.latin: comedebant et bibebant: uxores ducebant et nup-tias uxoribus tradebant, usque in diem qua intravit Noe in arcam: et venit diluvium, et perdidit omnes.
verses.english: they ate, they drank, they married wives, they were given in marriage, until the day that Noah entered the ark, and the flood came and destroyed them all.

verses.latin: Similiter et sicut factum est in diebus Lot: comedebant et bibebant, emebant et vendebant, plantabant et ædificabant:
verses.english: Likewise as it was also in the days of Lot: they ate, they drank, they bought, they sold, they planted, they built;

verses.latin: qua die autem exiit Lot de Sodomis, pluit ignem et sulphur de cœlo, et omnes perdidit:
verses.english: but on the day that Lot went out of Sodom it rained fire and brimstone from heaven and destroyed them all.

verses.latin: secundum hæc erit in die qua Filius hominis revelabitur.
verses.english: Even so will it be in the day when the Son of Man is revealed.

verses.latin: In illa hora, qui fuerit in tecto, et vasa ejus in domo, ne descendat tollere illa: et qui in agro, similiter non revertatur retro.
verses.english: In that day, he who is on the housetop, and his goods are in the house, let him not come down to take them away. And likewise the one who is in the field, let him not turn back.

verses.latin: Recordamini uxoris Lot.
verses.english: Remember Lot's wife.

verses.latin: Quicumque quæsierit animam suam salvam facere, perdet illam: et quicumque perdiderit illam, vivificabit eam.
verses.english: Whoever seeks to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life will preserve it.

verses.latin: Dico vobis: In illa nocte erunt duo in lecto uno: unus assumetur, et alter relinquetur.
verses.english: I tell you, in that night there will be two in one bed: one will be taken and the other will be left.

verses.latin: Duæ erunt molentes in unum: una assumetur, et altera relinquetur.
verses.english: Two women will be grinding together: the one will be taken and the other left.

verses.latin: Duo in agro: unus assumetur, et alter relinquetur.
verses.english: Two men will be in the field: one will be taken and the other left.

verses.latin: Respondentes dicunt illi: Ubi Domine? Qui dixit ad illos: Ubi corpus fuerit, illic congregabuntur et aquilæ.
verses.english: And answering, they said to Him, "Where, Lord?" And He said to them, "Wherever the body is, there the eagles will be gathered together."

verses.latin: Dixit autem parabolam ad illos, ad quos fiduciales erant in semetipsis tamquam justi, et aspernabantur ceteros:
verses.english: Jesus told this parable to those who were very confident in their own righteousness and who looked down on everyone else:

verses.latin: Duo homines ascenderunt in templum ut orarent: unus Pharisaeus, et alter publicanus.
verses.english: “Two men went up to the Temple to pray. One was a Pharisee, and the other was a tax collector.

verses.latin: Pharisaeus stans, hæc secum orabat: Deus, gratias ago tibi, quia non sum sicut ceteri hominum, rapaces, injusti, adulteri, velut et hic publicanus:
verses.english: “The Pharisee stood by himself and prayed, ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other people—thieves, rogues, adulterers—or even like this tax collector.

verses.latin: jejunio bis in sabbato: do decimam omnium quæ possideo.
verses.english: I fast twice a week, and I give a tenth of all I get.’

verses.latin: Publicanus autem, procul stans, nolebat nec oculos ad cælum levare: sed percutiebat pectus suum, dicens: Deus, propitius esto mihi peccatori.
verses.english: “But the tax collector stood at a distance and would not even look up to heaven, but beat his breast and said, ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner!’

verses.latin: Dico vobis, descendit hic justificatus in domum suam ab illo. Quia omnis qui se exaltat, humiliabitur: et qui se humiliat, exaltabitur.
verses.english: “I tell you, this man, rather than the other, went home justified before God. For all those who exalt themselves will be humbled, and those who humble themselves will be exalted.”

verses.latin: Adferbant autem ad illum et infantes, ut illos tangeret. Quod cum vidissent discipuli, increpabant illos.
verses.english: People were also bringing babies to Jesus for him to touch. When the disciples saw this, they rebuked them.

verses.latin: Jesus autem vocatis illis, dixit: Sinite pueros venire ad me, et nolite prohibere eos: talium est enim regnum Dei.
verses.english: But Jesus called the children to him and said, “Let the little children come to me, and do not hinder them, for to such belongs the kingdom of God.

verses.latin: Amen dico vobis, qui non susceperit regnum Dei sicut puer, non intrabit in illud.
verses.english: Truly I tell you, anyone who will not receive the kingdom of God like a little child will never enter it.”

verses.latin: Et interrogavit eum quidam princeps, dicens: Magister bone, quid faciens vitam æternam possidebo?
verses.english: A certain ruler asked him, “Good teacher, what must I do to inherit eternal life?”

verses.latin: Dixit autem illi Jesus: Quid me dicis bonum? nemo bonus nisi solus Deus.
verses.english: “Why do you call me good?” Jesus answered. “No one is good—except God alone.

verses.latin: Mandata nosti: non mœchaberis: non occides: non furaberis: non falsum testimonium dices: honora patrem tuum et matrem.
verses.english: You know the commandments: ‘You shall not commit adultery, you shall not murder, you shall not steal, you shall not give false testimony, honor your father and mother.’

verses.latin: Qui ait: Hæc omnia custodivi a juventute mea.
verses.english: “All these I have kept since I was a boy,” he replied.

verses.latin: Audito autem hoc Jesus, dixit ei: Adhuc unum tibi deest: vende omnia quæ habes, et distribue pauperibus, et habebis thesaurum in cælo: et veni, sequere me.
verses.english: When Jesus heard this, he said to him, “You still lack one thing. Sell everything you have and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven. Then come, follow me.”

verses.latin: His auditis, contristatus est: quia dives erat valde.
verses.english: When he heard this, he became very sad, because he was very wealthy.

verses.latin: Videns autem Jesus illum tristem factum, dixit: Quam difficile, qui pecunias habent, in regnum Dei intrabunt!
verses.english: Jesus looked at him and said, “How hard it is for the rich to enter the kingdom of God!

verses.latin: Facilius est enim camelum per foramen acus transire, quam divitem intrare in regnum Dei.
verses.english: Indeed, it is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for someone who is rich to enter the kingdom of God.”

verses.latin: Et qui audiebant, dixerunt: Et quis potest salvus fieri?
verses.english: Those who heard this asked, “Then who can be saved?”

verses.latin: Quibus ipse dixit: Quæ impossibilia sunt apud homines, possibilia sunt apud Deum.
verses.english: Jesus replied, “What is impossible for human beings is possible for God.”

verses.latin: Ait autem Petrus: Ecce nos dimisimus omnia, et secuti sumus te.
verses.english: Peter said, “We have left our own homes and followed you.”

verses.latin: Qui dixit ad illos: Amen dico vobis, nemo est qui reliquit domum, aut parentes, aut fratres, aut uxorem, aut filios propter regnum Dei,
verses.english: And he said to them, “Truly I tell you, there is no one who has left home or parents or brothers or sisters or wife or children for the sake of the kingdom of God

verses.latin: qui non recipiat multo plura in hoc tempore, et in sæculo futuro vitam æternam.
verses.english: who will not receive many times more in this age and, in the age to come, eternal life.”

verses.latin: Assumpsit autem Jesus duodecim, et ait illis: Ecce, ascendimus Jerosolymam, et consummabuntur omnia quæ scripta sunt per prophetas de Filio hominis.
verses.english: Then he took the Twelve aside and told them, “We are going up to Jerusalem, and everything that is written about the Son of Man by the prophets will be fulfilled.

verses.latin: Tradetur enim gentibus, et illudetur, et contumeliis afficietur, et conspuetur:
verses.english: He will be delivered over to the Gentiles, and will be mocked, insulted, and spat upon.

verses.latin: et flagellantes occident eum: et tertia die resurget.
verses.english: They will flog him and kill him, and on the third day he will rise again.”

verses.latin: Et ipsi nihil horum intellexerunt: et erat verbum istud latens ab eis, et non intelligebant quæ dicebantur.
verses.english: The disciples understood none of this. Its meaning was hidden from them, and they did not know what he was talking about.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum appropinquaret Jericho, cæcus quidam sedebat secus viam, mendicans.
verses.english: As Jesus approached Jericho, a blind beggar was sitting by the roadside.

verses.latin: Et cum audisset turbam prætereuntium, interrogabat quid hoc esset.
verses.english: When he heard the crowd going by, he asked what was happening.

verses.latin: Responderunt autem ei quod Jesus Nazarenus transiret.
verses.english: They told him, “Jesus of Nazareth is passing by.”

verses.latin: Et clamavit, dicens: Jesu, fili David, miserere mei.
verses.english: He cried out, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”

verses.latin: Et qui præibant, increpabant eum ut taceret. Ipse vero multo magis clamabat: Fili David, miserere mei.
verses.english: Those who were in front told him to be quiet, but he shouted all the more, “Son of David, have mercy on me!”

verses.latin: Stans autem Jesus, jussit illum adduci ad se. Et cum appropinquasset, interrogavit eum,
verses.english: Jesus stopped and ordered the man to be brought to him. When he came near, Jesus asked him,

verses.latin: dicens: Quid vis ut faciam tibi? At ille dixit: Domine, ut videam.
verses.english: “What do you want me to do for you?” “Lord,” he replied, “I want to see.”

verses.latin: Et Jesus dixit illi: Respice, fides tua te salvum fecit. Et confestim vidit, et sequebatur illum magnificans Deum: et omnis populus, ut vidit, dedit laudem Deo.
verses.english: Jesus said to him, “Receive your sight; your faith has healed you.” Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus, glorifying God. When all the people saw this, they also praised God.

verses.latin: Et ingressus, perambulabat Iericho.
verses.english: And having entered, He was passing through Jericho.

verses.latin: Et ecce vir, nomine Zachæus: et hic erat princeps publicanorum, et ipse dives:
verses.english: And behold, a man, by the name of Zacchaeus: and he was the chief of the tax collectors, and he himself was rich:

verses.latin: et quærebat videre Jesum, quis esset: et non poterat præ turba, quia statura pusillus erat.
verses.english: and he was seeking to see Jesus, who He was: and he could not because of the crowd, because he was small in stature.

verses.latin: Et præcurrens, cucurrit retro, et ascendit in arborem sycomorum ut videret eum: quia inde erat transiturus.
verses.english: And running ahead, he ran behind, and he climbed a sycamore tree to see Him: because He was to pass by that way.

verses.latin: Et cum venisset ad locum, suspiciens Jesus, vidit illum, et dixit ad eum: Zachæe, festinans descende: quia hodie in domo tua oportet me manere.
verses.english: And when He had come to the place, looking up, Jesus saw him, and said to him: "Zacchaeus, hurry down: because today I must stay in your house."

verses.latin: Et festinans descendit, et excepit illum gaudens.
verses.english: And he hurried down, and received Him, rejoicing.

verses.latin: Et cum viderent omnes, murmurabant, dicentes quod ad hominem peccatorem divertisset.
verses.english: And when all saw, they murmured, saying that He had turned aside to a sinful man.

verses.latin: Stans autem Zachæus, dixit ad Dominum: Ecce dimidium bonorum meorum, Domine, do pauperibus: et si quid aliquem defraudavi, reddo quadruplum.
verses.english: But standing, Zacchaeus said to the Lord: "Behold, Lord, I give half of my possessions to the poor: and if I have defrauded anyone, I restore fourfold."

verses.latin: Ait Jesus ad eum: Quia hodie salus huic domui facta est: eo quod et ipse filius sit Abrahæ.
verses.english: Jesus said to him: "Today salvation has come to this house: because he is also a son of Abraham."

verses.latin: Filius enim hominis venit quærere, et salvum facere quod perierat.
verses.english: For the Son of Man came to seek, and to save that which was lost.

verses.latin: Hæc autem illis audientibus, adjiciens dixit parabolam: eo quod esset prope Jerusalem, et existimarent quod confestim regnum Dei deberet manifestari.
verses.english: And while they were listening to these things, He added a parable: because He was near Jerusalem, and they thought that the kingdom of God should immediately appear.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo: Homo quidam nobilis abiit in regionem longinquam accipere sibi regnum, et reverti.
verses.english: He said therefore: "A certain nobleman went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom, and to return."

verses.latin: Vocatis autem decem servis suis, dedit eis decem talenta, et ait ad illos: Negotiamini dum venio.
verses.english: And calling his ten servants, he gave them ten talents, and said to them: 'Do business until I come."

verses.latin: Cives autem ejus odiebant eum: et miserunt legationem post illum, dicentes: Nolumus hunc regnare super nos.
verses.english: But his citizens hated him: and they sent a delegation after him, saying: 'We do not want this man to reign over us.'

verses.latin: Et factum est cum rediisset, accepto regno, jussit vocari servos illos, quibus dedit pecuniam, ut sciret quid negotiarent.
verses.english: And it came to pass that when he returned, having received the kingdom, he ordered those servants to be called, to whom he had given the money, that he might know what they had gained.

verses.latin: Venit autem primus, dicens: Domine, talentum tuum decem talentis acquisivit.
verses.english: And the first came, saying: 'Lord, your talent has gained ten talents.'

verses.latin: Et ait illi: Euge, bone serve: quia in modico fuisti fidelis, eris potestatem habens super decem civitates.
verses.english: And he said to him: 'Well done, good servant: because you have been faithful in a very little thing, you will have power over ten cities.'

verses.latin: Et alter venit, dicens: Domine, talentum tuum fecit quinque talenta.
verses.english: And the second came, saying: 'Lord, your talent has made five talents.'

verses.latin: Et huic ait: Et tu esto super quinque civitates.
verses.english: And to this one he said: 'You also shall be over five cities.'

verses.latin: Et alius venit, dicens: Domine, ecce talentum tuum, quod habui repositum in sudario:
verses.english: And another came, saying: 'Lord, behold, your talent, which I had put away in a napkin:

verses.latin: timui enim te, quia homo durus es: tollis quod non posuisti, et metis quod non seminasti.
verses.english: For I feared you, because you are a harsh man: you take up what you did not lay down, and you reap what you did not sow.'

verses.latin: Ait illi: De ore tuo te judico, serve nequam. Sciebas quod ego homo durus sum, tollens quod non posui, et metens quod non seminavi:
verses.english: He said to him: 'By your own mouth I judge you, wicked servant. You knew that I am a harsh man, taking up what I did not lay down, and reaping what I did not sow:

verses.latin: et quare non dedisti pecuniam meam ad mensam? et ego veniens cum usuris utique exegissem illam.
verses.english: and why did you not put my money at the table? And I, coming, might have required it with interest.'

verses.latin: Et his qui stabant, dixit: Tollite ab illo talentum, et date illi qui habet decem talenta.
verses.english: And to those who were standing there, he said: 'Take the talent from him, and give it to the one who has ten talents.'

verses.latin: Et dixerunt ei: Domine, habet decem talenta.
verses.english: And they said to him: 'Lord, he has ten talents.'

verses.latin: Dico autem vobis, quia omni habenti dabitur, et ab eo qui non habet, et quod habet auferetur ab eo.
verses.english: I tell you, because to everyone who has, more will be given, and from him who does not have, even what he has will be taken away from him.

verses.latin: Verumtamen inimicos meos illos, qui noluerunt me regnare super se, adducite huc, et interficite ante me.
verses.english: But as for those enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here, and kill them before me.'

verses.latin: Et hæc dicto, præcedebat ascendens in Ierosolymam.
verses.english: And when He had said these things, He went on, going up to Jerusalem.

verses.latin: Et factum est, cum appropinquasset ad Bethphage et Bethaniam, ad montem qui vocatur Oliveti, misit duos discipulos suos,
verses.english: And it happened, when He had come near to Bethphage and Bethany, to the mountain that is called Olivet, He sent two of His disciples,

verses.latin: dicens: Ite in castellum, quod contra est: in quo introeuntes, invenietis pullum asinae vinctum, cui nemo umquam hominum sedit: solvite illum, et adducite.
verses.english: saying: 'Go into the village which is opposite you: entering into it, you will find a colt of an ass tied, on which no one has ever sat: untie him, and bring him.'

verses.latin: Et si quis vos interrogaverit: Quare solvitis? sic dicetis ei: Quia Dominus operam ejus necessariam habet.
verses.english: And if anyone asks you: "Why are you untying it?" so shall you say to him: 'Because the Lord has need of his service.'

verses.latin: Abierunt autem qui missi erant, et ita invenerunt sicut dixit illis.
verses.english: And they that were sent went, and found it as He had told them.

verses.latin: Solventibus autem illis pullum, dixerunt domini ejus ad illos: Quid solvitis pullum?
verses.english: And as they were untying the colt, its owners said to them: 'Why are you untying the colt?'

verses.latin: At illi dixerunt: Quia Dominus opus habet ei.
verses.english: And they said: 'Because the Lord has need of him.'

verses.latin: Et duxerunt illum ad Jesum: et, jactis vestimentis suis super pullum, imposuerunt Jesum.
verses.english: And they led him to Jesus: and casting their garments on the colt, they placed Jesus on it.

verses.latin: Eunte autem illo, subiciebant vestimenta sua in via.
verses.english: And as He went, they spread their garments in the way.

verses.latin: Cumque jam appropinquasset ad descensum montis Oliveti, cœperunt omnes turba discipulorum gaudentes laudare Deum voce magna super omnibus, quæ viderant virtutibus,
verses.english: And when He was now approaching the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples, rejoicing, began to praise God with a loud voice for all the miracles that they had seen,

verses.latin: dicentes: Benedictus qui venit rex in nomine Domini: pax in cælo, et gloria in excelsis.
verses.english: saying: "Blessed is the King who comes in the name of the Lord: peace in heaven, and glory in the highest."

verses.latin: Et quidam pharisæorum de turba, dixerunt ad eum: Magister, increpa discipulos tuos.
verses.english: And some of the Pharisees from the crowd said to Him: "Teacher, rebuke your disciples."

verses.latin: Quibus ipse ait: Dico vobis, quia si hi tacuerint, lapides clamabunt.
verses.english: To whom He said: "I tell you, that if these should be silent, the stones will cry out."

verses.latin: Et ut appropinquavit, videns civitatem, flevit super illam,
verses.english: And when He drew near, seeing the city, He wept over it,

verses.latin: dicens: Quia si cognovisses et tu, et quidem in hac die tua, quæ ad pacem tuam: nunc autem abscondita sunt ab oculis tuis.
verses.english: saying: "If only you had known, even you, and especially on this day, the things that belong to your peace: but now they are hidden from your eyes.

verses.latin: Quia venient dies in te: et circumdābunt te inimici tui vallo, et circuibunt te, et arctabunt te undique:
verses.english: For the days will come upon you: and your enemies will build a rampart around you, and they will encircle you and hem you in on every side:

verses.latin: et conterent te, et filios tuos qui sunt in te: et non relinquent in te lapidem super lapidem: propterea quod non cognovisti tempus visitationis tuæ.
verses.english: and they will dash you to the ground, and your children within you: and they will not leave in you one stone upon another: because you did not know the time of your visitation."

verses.latin: Et ingressus in templum, cœpit ejicere vendentes et ementes in illo,
verses.english: And entering the temple, He began to cast out those who were selling and buying in it,

verses.latin: dicens eis: Scriptum est: Quia domus mea, domus orationis est. Vos autem fecistis illam speluncam latronum.
verses.english: saying to them: "It is written: 'My house is a house of prayer.' But you have made it a den of thieves."

verses.latin: Et erat docens quotidie in templo. Principes autem sacerdotum, et scribæ, et principes plebis quærebant eum perdere:
verses.english: And He was teaching daily in the temple. But the chief priests, and the scribes, and the chief men of the people sought to destroy Him:

verses.latin: et non inveniebant quid facerent illi: omnes enim populus pendebat ei, audiens.
verses.english: and they did not find what they could do to Him: for all the people were hanging on to Him, listening.

verses.latin: Et factum est in una dierum, docente illo populum in templo, et evangelizante, supervenerunt principes sacerdotum, et scribae cum senioribus,
verses.english: One day, as Jesus was teaching the crowds in the Temple and preaching the Good News, the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders came up to Him.

verses.latin: dicentes: Dic nobis, in qua potestate haec facis? aut quis est, qui tibi dedit hanc potestatem?
verses.english: They said: “Tell us, by what authority do You do these things? Or who gave You this authority?”

verses.latin: Respondens autem dixit ad illos: Interrogabo vos et ego unum verbum, et respondete mihi:
verses.english: Jesus answered, saying to them: “I will also ask you one question. Answer Me,

verses.latin: baptisma Ioannis de caelo erat, an ex hominibus?
verses.english: Was John’s baptism from Heaven, or from men?”

verses.latin: At illi cogitabant inter se, dicentes: Quia si dixerimus: De caelo, dicet: Quare ergo non credidistis illi?
verses.english: They reasoned among themselves, saying: “If we say, ‘From Heaven,’ He will say, ‘Why then did you not believe him?’

verses.latin: Si autem dixerimus: Ex hominibus, totus populus lapidabit nos: certi sunt enim Ioannem prophetam habere.
verses.english: But if we say, ‘From men,’ all the people will stone us, because they are certain that John was a prophet.”

verses.latin: Et responderunt se nescire unde esset.
verses.english: So they answered that they did not know where it was from.

verses.latin: Et Jesus ait illis: Nec ego dico vobis in qua potestate haec facio.
verses.english: Jesus said to them: “Then neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.”

verses.latin: Coepit autem dicere ad plebem parabolam hanc: Homo quidam plantavit vineam, et locavit eam colonis, et peregre profectus est multis temporibus.
verses.english: Then He began to tell the people this parable: “A man planted a vineyard, leased it to tenant farmers, and went away for a long time.

verses.latin: Et in tempore misit ad colonos servum, ut de fructu vineae darent illi. Qui colonica, caedentes illum, vacuam dimiserunt.
verses.english: At the right time, he sent a servant to the tenant farmers, so they would give him some of the fruit of the vineyard. But the tenant farmers, after beating him, sent him away empty-handed.

verses.latin: Et addidit mittere alium servum: illi autem illum caedentes, et contumelia affectum, dimiserunt vacuum.
verses.english: So he sent another servant, but they beat him, insulted him, and sent him away empty-handed as well.

verses.latin: Et addidit mittere tertium: et illi hunc vulnerantes ejecerunt.
verses.english: Then he sent a third servant. They wounded this one and threw him out.

verses.latin: Dixit autem dominus vineae: Quid faciam? Mittam filium meum dilectum: forsitan hunc verebuntur.
verses.english: Then the owner of the vineyard said, ‘What should I do? I will send my beloved son. Surely they will respect him.’

verses.latin: Quem cum vidissent coloni, cogitaverunt inter se, dicentes: Hic est haeres, occidamus illum, ut nostra sit haereditas.
verses.english: But when the tenant farmers saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, ‘This is the heir. Let us kill him, so that the inheritance will be ours.’

verses.latin: Et ejicientes eum extra vineam, occiderunt. Quid ergo faciet illis dominus vineae?
verses.english: So they cast him out of the vineyard and killed him. What, then, will the owner of the vineyard do to them?

verses.latin: Veniet, et perdet colonos istos, et dabit vineam aliis. Quo audito, dixerunt illi: Absit.
verses.english: He will come and destroy those tenant farmers and will give the vineyard to others.” Hearing this, they said: “May it never be!”

verses.latin: Ipse autem aspiciens eos, dixit: Quid est ergo hoc quod scriptum est: Lapidem quem reprobaverunt aedificantes, hic factus est in caput anguli?
verses.english: But looking at them, He said: “Then what does this Scripture mean: ‘The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone’?

verses.latin: Omnis qui ceciderit super illum lapidem, confringetur: super quem autem ceciderit, conteret illum.
verses.english: “Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces, and upon whomever it falls, it will crush him.”

verses.latin: Et quaerebant principes sacerdotum, et scribae, mittere in illum manus illa hora: et timuerunt populum: cognoverant enim quod ad ipsos dixerat parabolam istam.
verses.english: The chief priests and the scribes sought to arrest Him that very hour, but they feared the people, because they knew He had spoken this parable against them.

verses.latin: Et observantes miserunt speculatores, qui simularent se justos esse, ut caperent eum in sermone, et traderent illum principatui, et potestati praesidis.
verses.english: Watching closely, they sent spies who pretended to be righteous, to trap Him in His speech, so that they could hand Him over to the authority and the power of the governor.

verses.latin: Et interrogaverunt eum, dicentes: Magister, scimus quia recte dicis et doces, et non accipis personam, sed in veritate viam Dei doces:
verses.english: So they questioned Him, saying: “Teacher, we know that You speak and teach correctly, and that You do not show partiality, but teach the way of God in truth.

verses.latin: Licet nobis dari tributum Caesari, an non?
verses.english: Is it lawful for us to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?”

verses.latin: Considerans autem dolum illorum, dixit ad illos: Quid me tentatis?
verses.english: But He perceived their craftiness and said to them: “Why do you test Me?

verses.latin: Ostendite mihi denarium. Cujus est imago et inscriptio?
verses.english: Show Me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have?”

verses.latin: Responderunt: Caesaris. Et ait illis: Reddite igitur quae sunt Caesaris, Caesari: et quae sunt Dei, Deo.
verses.english: They replied, “Caesar’s.” So He said to them: “Then render to Caesar the things that are Caesar’s, and to God the things that are God’s.”

verses.latin: Et non potuerunt verbum ejus reprehendere coram plebe: et mirati in responso ejus, tacuerunt.
verses.english: They could not take hold of His word in front of the people, and being amazed at His answer, they became silent.

verses.latin: Accesserunt autem quidam Sadducaeorum, qui negant resurrectionem, et interrogaverunt eum,
verses.english: Then some Sadducees came up to Him, who deny the resurrection, and they questioned Him,

verses.latin: dicentes: Magister, Moyses scripsit nobis: Si frater alicujus mortuus fuerit habens uxorem, et hic sine filiis fuerit, ut accipiat eam frater ejus uxorem, et suscitet semen fratri suo.
verses.english: saying: “Teacher, Moses wrote for us that if a man’s brother dies, leaving a wife but no children, the man must take the wife and raise up offspring for his brother.

verses.latin: Septem ergo fratres erant: et primus accepit uxorem, et mortuus est sine filiis.
verses.english: Now there were seven brothers. The first took a wife, but died childless.

verses.latin: Et secundus accepit illam, et hic mortuus est sine filio.
verses.english: Then the second and third brother married her,

verses.latin: Et tertius accepit illam: et similiter et omnes septem, et non reliquerunt filios, et mortui sunt.
verses.english: and the third took her, and in the same way all seven, but they left no children and died.

verses.latin: Novissime autem omnium et mulier mortua est.
verses.english: Finally, the woman died too.

verses.latin: In resurrectione ergo cujus uxorem de illis erit? omnes enim septem habuerunt eam uxorem.
verses.english: Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife will she be? For all seven had her as a wife.”

verses.latin: Et ait illis Jesus: Filii saeculi hujus nubunt et traduntur ad nuptias:
verses.english: Jesus said to them: “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage,

verses.latin: illi autem qui digni habentur saeculo illo, et resurrectione ex mortuis, neque nubent, neque nubentur.
verses.english: but those who are considered worthy to attain the next age and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry nor are given in marriage.

verses.latin: Neque enim jam possunt mori: nam sunt filii Dei, cum sint filii resurrectionis.
verses.english: For they cannot die anymore, since they are equal to the angels and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.

verses.latin: Quia vero resurgunt mortui, et Moyses ostendit, in rubo, sicut dicit Dominum Deum Abraham, et Deum Isaac, et Deum Jacob:
verses.english: But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed in the passage about the bush, where he calls the Lord the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.

verses.latin: Deus autem non est mortuorum, sed vivorum: omnes enim ei vivunt.
verses.english: Now He is not the God of the dead, but of the living, for to Him all are alive.”

verses.latin: Respondentes autem quidam scribarum, dixerunt: Magister, bene dixisti.
verses.english: Some of the scribes answered, “Teacher, You have spoken well.”

verses.latin: Et amplius non audebant eum quicquam interrogar.
verses.english: And they dared not question Him any further.

verses.latin: Ait autem ad illos: Quomodo dicunt Christum filium David esse?
verses.english: Then He said to them: “How do they say that the Christ is David’s son?

verses.latin: Ipse enim David dicit in libro Psalmorum: Dixit Dominus Domino meo: Sede a dextris meis,
verses.english: For David himself says in the Book of Psalms: ‘The Lord said to my Lord, “Sit at My right hand,

verses.latin: donec ponam inimicos tuos scabellum pedum tuorum.
verses.english: until I make Your enemies a footstool for Your feet.”’

verses.latin: David ergo Dominum illum vocat: et quomodo filius ejus est?
verses.english: David therefore calls Him Lord, so how is He his son?

verses.latin: Audiente autem omni populo, dixit discipulis suis:
verses.english: As all the people were listening, He said to His disciples:

verses.latin: Attendite a scribis, qui volunt ambulare in stolis, et amant salutationes in foro, et primas cathedras in synagogis, et primos discubitus in conviviis:
verses.english: “Beware of the scribes, who like to walk around in long robes, and love greetings in the marketplaces, and the best seats in the synagogues, and the places of honor at banquets.

verses.latin: qui devorant domos viduarum, simulantes longas orationes: hi accipient damnationem majorem.
verses.english: They devour the houses of widows, pretending to pray at length; these will receive a greater condemnation.”

verses.latin: Et cum extendisset oculos suos, vidit eos, qui mittebant dona sua in gazophylacium.
verses.english: And having raised His eyes, He saw those who were throwing their gifts into the treasury.

verses.latin: Vidit autem et quamdam viduam pauperculam mittentem ibi duo minuta.
verses.english: He also saw a certain poor widow putting in two mites.

verses.latin: Et dixit: Vere dico vobis, quia vidua haec pauperior quam omnes misit.
verses.english: And He said: "Truly, I say to you, that this poor widow put in more than all the rest.

verses.latin: Omnes enim hi ex abundanti sibi miserunt in opera Dei: haec autem de eo, quod deest illi, omnem victum suum misit.
verses.english: For all these put in gifts out of their abundance, into the works of God: but she from that which she lacks, she put in her whole living."

verses.latin: Et quibusdam dicentibus de templo, quod bonis lapidibus et donis ornatum esset, dixit:
verses.english: And as some were speaking of the temple, how it was adorned with good stones and gifts, He said:

verses.latin: Haec quae videtis, venient dies in quibus non relinquetur lapis super lapidem, qui non destruatur.
verses.english: "These things which you see, the days will come in which there will not be left a stone upon a stone that will not be torn down."

verses.latin: Interrogaverunt autem eum dicentes: Magister, quando haec erunt? et quod signum erit, quando haec futura sunt?
verses.english: And they asked Him, saying: "Teacher, when will these things be? And what sign will there be when these things are about to happen?"

verses.latin: Qui dixit: Videte ne seducamini: multi enim venient in nomine meo, dicentes: Ego sum, et tempus appropinquavit: nolite ergo ire post illos.
verses.english: Who said: "See that you are not seduced; for many will come in My name, saying, 'I am He,' and 'The time is at hand.' Do not therefore go after them.

verses.latin: Cum audieritis autem bella et seditiones, nolite terreri: oportet primum haec fieri, sed nondum statim finis.
verses.english: And when you shall hear of wars and seditions, do not be terrified; for these things must come to pass first, but the end is not immediately."

verses.latin: Tunc dicebat illis: Surget gens contra gentem, et regnum adversus regnum.
verses.english: Then He said to them: "Nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.

verses.latin: Et terraemotus magni erunt per loca, et pestilentiae, et fames: terroresque de caelo, et signa magna erunt.
verses.english: And great earthquakes will be in various places, and plagues, and famines; and terrors from heaven, and great signs will be.

verses.latin: Sed ante haec omnia, mittent in vos manus suas, et persequentur, tradentes in synagogas et carceres, trahentes ad reges et praesides propter nomen meum.
verses.english: But before all these things, they will lay their hands on you, and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues and prisons, dragging you to kings and governors for My name's sake.

verses.latin: Et eveniet vobis in testimonium.
verses.english: And this will be for a testimony to you.

verses.latin: Ponete ergo in cordibus vestris, non praemeditari quomodo respondeatis.
verses.english: Therefore lay it up in your hearts, not to meditate beforehand how you should answer.

verses.latin: Ego enim dabo vobis os et sapientiam, cui non poterunt resistere, neque contradicere omnes adversarii vestri.
verses.english: For I will give you a mouth and wisdom, which all your adversaries will not be able to resist or contradict.

verses.latin: Trademini autem a parentibus et fratribus, et propinquis et amicis: et morte afficient ex vobis.
verses.english: But you will be delivered up even by parents, and brothers, and relatives, and friends; and some of you they will put to death.

verses.latin: Et eritis odio omnibus propter nomen meum.
verses.english: And you will be hated by all because of My name.

verses.latin: Et capillus de capite vestro non peribit.
verses.english: And not a hair of your head will perish.

verses.latin: In patientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras.
verses.english: In your patience you will possess your souls.

verses.latin: Cum autem videritis Jerusalem circumdari ab exercitu, tunc scitote quia appropinquavit desolatio ejus.
verses.english: And when you shall see Jerusalem surrounded by an army, then know that its desolation has drawn near.

verses.latin: Tunc qui in Judaea sunt, fugiant ad montes: et qui in medio ejus, discedant: et qui in regionibus, non intrent in eam.
verses.english: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains; and those who are in the midst of it, depart; and those who are in the regions, not enter into it.

verses.latin: Quia dies ultionis hi sunt, ut impleantur omnia quae scripta sunt.
verses.english: For these are the days of vengeance, that all things which are written may be fulfilled.

verses.latin: Vae autem praegnantibus et nutrientibus in illis diebus: erit enim pressura magna in terra, et ira populo huic.
verses.english: But woe to those who are pregnant and nursing in those days; for there will be great distress in the land, and wrath upon this people.

verses.latin: Et cadet in ore gladii, et captivi ducentur in omnes gentes: et Jerusalem calcabitur a gentibus, donec impleantur tempora gentium.
verses.english: And they will fall by the edge of the sword, and be led captive into all nations; and Jerusalem will be trodden down by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.

verses.latin: Et erunt signa in sole et luna et stellis: et in terris pressura gentium prae confusione sonitus maris et fluctuum,
verses.english: And there will be signs in the sun and moon and stars; and upon the earth distress of nations by reason of the confusion of the roaring of the sea and the waves,

verses.latin: aridis hominum prae timore et expectatione eorum quae supervenient universo orbi: nam virtutes caelorum movebuntur.
verses.english: men withering away for fear, and for expectation of the things which will come upon the whole world: for the powers of the heavens will be moved.

verses.latin: Et tunc videbunt Filium hominis venientem in nube cum potestate magna et majestate.
verses.english: And then they will see the Son of Man coming in a cloud with great power and majesty.

verses.latin: His autem fieri coeptis, respicite et levate capita vestra: quoniam appropinquat redemptio vestra.
verses.english: And when these things begin to happen, look up and lift up your heads, because your redemption draws near.

verses.latin: Et dixit illis similitudinem: Videte ficulneam, et omnes arbores:
verses.english: And He spoke to them a parable: "See the fig tree, and all the trees:

verses.latin: cum proferunt jam, scitis quod prope est aestas.
verses.english: When they are already budding, you know that summer is near.

verses.latin: Ita et vos cum videritis haec fieri, scitote quod prope est regnum Dei.
verses.english: So you also, when you see these things happen, know that the kingdom of God is near.

verses.latin: Amen dico vobis, quia non praeteribit generatio haec, donec omnia fiant.
verses.english: Amen I say to you, that this generation will not pass away, until all things are fulfilled.

verses.latin: Caelum et terra transibunt: verba autem mea non praeteribunt.
verses.english: The universe and the earth will pass away, but My words will not pass away.

verses.latin: Attendite vobis, ne forte graventur corda vestra in crapula et ebrietate, et curis hujus vitae: et superveniat in vos repentina dies illa.
verses.english: And take heed to yourselves, lest perhaps your hearts be weighed down with overeating and drunkenness and the cares of this life; and that day come upon you suddenly.

verses.latin: Tamquam laqueus enim veniet super omnes qui sedent super faciem universae terrae.
verses.english: For as a snare it will come upon all those who sit upon the face of the whole earth.

verses.latin: Vigilate itaque, omni tempore orantes, ut digni habeamini fugere ista omnia quae ventura sunt, et stare ante Filium hominis.
verses.english: Watch therefore, praying at all times, that you may be accounted worthy to escape all these things that are to come, and to stand before the Son of Man.

verses.latin: Erat autem diebus docens in templo, et noctibus exiens, morabatur in monte qui vocatur Oliveti.
verses.english: And in the daytime He was teaching in the temple; and going out in the night, He would stay at the mountain which is called Olivet.

verses.latin: Et omnis populus manebat in eum audiens in templo.
verses.english: And all the people came early in the morning to Him in the temple to listen to Him.

verses.latin: Appropinquabat autem dies festorum Azymorum, qui dicitur Pascha.
verses.english: The feast of Unleavened Bread, which is called the Passover, was now approaching.

verses.latin: Et quærebant principes sacerdotum et scribæ quomodo eum interficerent: timebant vero populum.
verses.english: The chief priests and the scribes were seeking how to put Him to death, but they were afraid of the people.

verses.latin: Intravit autem Satanas in Judam, qui cognominabatur Iscariotes, unum de duodecim.
verses.english: Then Satan entered into Judas, who was surnamed Iscariot, one of the twelve.

verses.latin: Et abiit, et locutus est cum principibus sacerdotum, et magistratibus, quomodo illum traderet eis.
verses.english: And he went away, and he spoke with the chief priests and the captains about how he might betray Him to them.

verses.latin: Et gavisi sunt, et pacti sunt pecuniam illi dare.
verses.english: They were glad, and they agreed to give him money.

verses.latin: Et pollicitus est, et quærebat opportunitatem ut traderet eum inabsente turba.
verses.english: And he promised, and he sought an opportunity to betray Him in the absence of the crowd.

verses.latin: Venit autem dies Azymorum, in qua oportebat immolari Pascha.
verses.english: Then came the day of the Unleavened Bread, on which it was necessary that the Passover should be sacrificed.

verses.latin: Misitque Petrum et Joannem, dicens: Ite, et parate nobis Pascha, ut manducemus.
verses.english: And He sent Peter and John, saying: “Go and prepare the Passover for us that we may eat.”

verses.latin: At illi dixerunt: Ubi vis paremus?
verses.english: But they said, “Where do you want us to prepare it?”

verses.latin: Et dixit eis: Ecce, introëuntibus vobis in civitatem, occurret vobis homo lagenam aquae portans: sequimini eum in domum, in quam intrat.
